title: HOA obtained a judgement against me before foreclosure. The property was sold a year ago, they are now trying to collect?
question: Judgement was in 2011 but HOA did not collect while trying to complete a shotsale, then a deed in lieu, bank finally foreclosed. Property was sold in July of 2012. HOA is now trying to collect on judgement. Can they? Shouldn't it have been settled in order to sell property?
question_tags: Business contracts,Bankruptcy,Chapter 7 bankruptcy means test,Debt,Debt settlement,Bankruptcy and debt,Residential property,Foreclosure,Homeowners' association,Tax law
answers: A money judgment was entered against you personally. Unless you have a good reason to set aside the judgment (such as no notification or knowledge that you were being sued), the money judgment is valid and can be enforced.

Its clear that you have a personal liability to the HOAs and I would ask whether you have additional liabilities stemming from the foreclosure such as a second mortgage or 1099 IRS liability for cancelled debt on the First Deed of Trust. I would run a means test to see if you qualify for bankruptcy or explore debt settlement. The devils in the details as to which is the best choice for you. JOE

There is one scenario that would prevent the HOA from collecting from you, in this busy fact history, which is that only one recovery can be made for the debt.
If there was a foreclosure and bank sale in 2012, it is possible the back HOA dues were brought up to date by the new owner, in that event the HOA is not allowed to collect twice, which would be the situation if the collection from you was made after the HOA dues had been btrought up to date.
Otherwise, you remain a target as described by my colleagues.
Good luck.

Not necessarily. The HOA dues, special assessments and fines run personally to the homeowner. So the HOA will most often pursue the former homeowner. If your HOA house is foreclosed on, you still have to pay the dues until the bank sells it to a third party and the title is not in your name anymore. The fines and fees of an HOA are a matter of private contract between the HOA and the homeowner--the CC&Rs are the contract. So they are not going to pursue anyone else for it, nor are they obligated to take it out of the house escrow/foreclosure transaction. They are pursuing you based on a breach of contract--not the foreclosure of your house, they are not the lender.

The HOA has the option to pursue their remedies against the property or against you personally. It is their choice, not yours. Clearly the value of the property was considered insufficient to support their claim which is why they are now looking to obtain payment from you. Hope this perspective helps!
